markdownRemark.html:
In 2016, My dad and I shaped a hollow wooden paulownia surfboard with the help of Greg Facer, who used to live in Sydney and fully helped us step-by-step with the process of boardmaking and supplied us with the elusive paulownia wood that was pretty hard to get.

The board came out awesome and surfs really well. I definitely want to build another shorter timber one in the near future.

This wooden surfboard making experience made me want to shape a foam and fibreglass surfboard, so I’ve started designing it on CAD and making templates so that I can start making it. I’ve purchased a shortboard blank from surfblanks brookvale.

I will be updating this page throughout the process of making my first board and also including any problems that I encounter or any things I learn from making the board.

This blank I bought is already pretty skinny, so cant take much off. Its 6ft in length, and I’m planning to make the board around 5’10 so that might be a challenge but I’ll see how it goes.

Creating the board on CAD

![](./images/1.jpg

My design on Shape 3DX in imperial measurements.

I bought a one year design license for around $60 AUD, pretty pricey but it’s a good software for measurements and will definetely help to get the board pretty accurate. The dimensions I want for this board are 5’10 x 19 3/16 x 2 3/8, which should end up being around 28.4L. Bit chunkier than I usually ride, but I think it should be fine.

![](./images/3.jpg

My design on Shape 3DX in metric measurements. I will probably use metric most of the time as it’s more exact.

![](./images/4.jpg

A summary of the rounded squash performer with metric measurements and approximate volume.

![](./images/5.jpg

A better photo of the rocker and the curves on the board. You can see the vee outline on the underside on the middle profile.

![](./images/6.jpg

A rendered version of how the board should look. I’m still not sure if I want to add some timber on top of the foam to make it stronger but I’ll see. Definetely going to try do some cool board art.

![](./images/7.jpg

The underside of the board

![](./images/8.jpg

The rocker
